Fig. 1 Illustrations of the base epoxy agent and amine curing agent. 2D (top) and 3D (bottom) structures of (a) DGEBA and (b) 2,2′-CH3-BP. Epoxy resins, which are common matrices in carbon fibre-reinforced plastics, are derived from the curing of epoxy amines. Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations are commonly used to model the physical properties of such network polymers, but they do not account for chemical reactions. Quantum chemical (QC) calculations can elucidate reaction mechanisms and energies but are not suitable for models with thousands of atoms. To address these limitations, in this study, we developed a new method, cat-GRRM/MC/MD, that combines QC calculations in the Global Reaction Route Mapping (GRRM) program with reaction simulations involved in MD simulation methods. This approach allows the simulation of reaction pathways in which proton donor molecules such as alcohols and amines act as molecular catalysts (autocatalysis), and the reaction kinetics are realised in a Monte Carlo (MC) manner. Our results show that autocatalysis significantly reduces the activation energy of the epoxy resin reaction, bringing the calculated data closer to the experimental results. When these quantum chemical calculations were incorporated into MD simulations, it was found that the activation energy influenced the crosslinking results. Models including catalysis led to network polymers with larger carbon skeletons, and physical properties such as the Young's modulus and glass transition temperature become closer to experimental results. This study not only deepens our understanding of the mechanism of the self-catalytic reaction of epoxy resins but also provides a new tool for accurately simulating the performance of epoxy resins, thus enabling more precise control of their properties. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords MD simulation Transition state Young's modulus Polymer Autocatalysis Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Carbon-fibre-reinforced plastics (CFRPs) are composite materials comprising matrix resins, such as epoxy, and carbon fibres. CFRPs have the advantages of high specific strength and stiffness as well as light weight and are therefore widely used in many fields, including aerospace manufacturing [1]. These properties result from the three-dimensional (3D) cross-linked structures of the CFRPs. However, determining the properties experimentally is time-consuming and expensive; simulations provide an affordable alternative [2]. Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations are amongst the most popular simulation methods for predicting the physical properties of polymers. Several MD simulations have been developed for reproducing the crosslinking process in thermosetting systems [3,4]. For instance, Komarov et al. [5] developed an MC/MD reaction model to simulate the mechanical characteristics of cured products. However, they did not consider reaction energies such as the activation energy (E a) and heat of formation (HOF). Estridge [6] emphasized the importance of adding reaction energies to the reaction criteria by examining the effect of the relative reaction rates between epoxy–primary amine and epoxy–secondary amine. It is worth noting that many simulation schemes have been proposed over the past decades. Nonetheless, a significant portion of these methods predominantly emphasize distance-based reaction criteria in atomistic simulations. Alternatively, they depend on coarse-grained simulations, which initially form the network and subsequently revert to more detailed atomistic simulations. While both methods facilitate the generation of atomic polymer networks, the resulting networks only provide an idealized representation of the actual events that occur during the curing of thermoset materials. For example, in an epoxy-amine cure reaction, there are two distinct steps: the primary amine reaction and the secondary amine reaction. The E a and HOF of these two steps are different. Therefore, relying only on atomic distances to determine the occurrence of a reaction results in an idealized representation of the constructed polymer structure, and the mechanical properties predicted by this approach may not accurately reflect actual performance. While MD simulations are commonly used for predicting the physical properties of network polymers, they do not account for chemical reactions. In cases where the chemical reaction process and mechanism need to be considered, relying solely on MD simulations is insufficient. Quantum chemical (QC) calculations can provide insights into chemical reaction pathways and energy, but they are not suitable for systems over thousands of atoms. Therefore, a more effective method is to combine QC calculations with MD simulations. Okabe et al. [7] developed a simulation model that considered both the distance of reactive parts and reaction energies by calculating the reaction energies and incorporating them into MD simulations. Kawagoe et al. [8] extended this reaction model to dissipative particle dynamics and enabled fast and large-scale curing simulations. Yamamoto et al. [9] developed an MD simulation model with both the distance and reaction energies to explore the adhesive strength of epoxy resin; however, they did not consider molecular catalysis during the curing process. Ehlers et al. [10] theoretically investigated epoxy–amine reactions using simplified molecular models and found that additional alcohol or amine molecules acted as catalysts for the reactions. Therefore, the catalytic effect should also be considered in simulations to accurately predict the physical properties of thermosetting systems. In this study, to further refine the simulation model for the curing reaction for epoxy resins, we incorporated the catalytic effect into the reaction model in an MD simulation by developing a novel method, cat-GRRM/MC/MD, that combines QC calculations in the Global Reaction Route Mapping (GRRM) program with reaction simulations involved in MD simulation methods. The diglycidyl ether of bisphenol A (DGEBA) and 4,4′-diamino-2,2′-dimethylbiphenyl (2,2′-CH3-BP) were selected as the base resin and curing agent, respectively; illustrations of their molecules are shown in Fig. 1 . The chemical reactions between DGEBA and 2,2′-CH3-BP were examined, and the results were compared with experimental results to confirm the validity of the simulation method. Our method explores the chemical reaction process and mechanism of the epoxy-amine curing reaction. In comparison to existing methods, we additionally account for the influence of the catalyst and employ actual molecules rather than the previous simplified model. Subsequently, reaction energy and catalytic effect are incorporated into the MD simulation for a more realistic prediction of network polymer properties. 2 Methods We combined GRRM and MD to develop a cross-linking model. The GRRM [11] program searches for reaction pathways between reactants and products and shows transition state (TS) structures and the corresponding E a. We therefore used the GRRM program combined with the first principle method to analyse the curing reaction mechanism. The first principle calculations were performed using a quantum chemistry package program (Gaussian16 [12]) at the restricted Hartree–Fock SCF level of theory with a 3–21 G basis set for all atoms (RHF/3–21 G). The GRRM program allows us to calculate not only the simplified model, but the actual molecular models for the epoxy and curing agents. The E a and HOF values obtained using GRRM were then applied to a MD simulation. For the MD simulation, we improved upon the reaction model proposed by Okabe et al. [7] to simulate the crosslinking reactions by including catalytic effects. Our previous study also used this modified model, as described by Zhao et al. [13]. We used a large-scale atomic/molecular massively parallel simulator (LAMMPS) [14] with a DREIDING force field [15]. The input geometries of the individual molecules were obtained by optimising one molecule extracted from the equilibrium structure in the reaction route calculations. The charges assigned to the atoms for the MD simulation were obtained using the restrained electrostatic potential (RESP) method [16]. Fig. 2 provides a flowchart of the overall procedure, and the details of the method are described in the following Sections 2.1 and 2.2. 2.1 Calculation of the reaction routes We used tools such as artificial force-induced reaction (AFIR) [11,17], minimum point optimization (MIN) [18], sphere-contraction-walk (SCW) [11], and two-point scaled hypersphere search algorithm (2PSHS) [19–21] in the GRRM program to automatically search for complete reaction pathways. In the first step, we built an initial structure containing unreacted epoxy resin base agent and the curing agent using GaussView [22]. We subsequently employed the semi-empirical method PM7 to identify the equilibrium structures of the reactants. After running the calculation for a predetermined duration (ranging from days to a week), we terminated the process. From the resultant equilibrium structures, the configuration with the relatively lowest energy was selected. And then, the AFIR method to obtain the required product. AFIR can explore reaction pathways by applying an artificial binding force that exceeds the reaction barrier, allowing reactants to combine rapidly. The obtained reactant and product were optimized using a stationary point search with MIN. The reaction pathway was then investigated using SCW and 2PSHS. SCW can identify intermediates between two structures, while 2PSHS finds TSs between two intermediates. The combination of SCW and 2PSHS can therefore be used to search for the TS structure between the two optimized structures. Using AFIR–SCW–2PSHS, we can obtain a complete reaction pathway including reactants, TSs, and products. The AFIR–MIN–SCW–2PSHS method is capable of accurately identifying the reaction pathways for direct reactions owing to their relative simplicity. However, for more complex pathways such as catalytic reactions, this method may deviate from the expected pathway, making it difficult to identify the intended reaction TSs. For more complex reaction pathways, the GRRM program is equipped with an algorithm that performs structural optimisation with very high accuracy, and, in addition to MIN, saddle-point optimisation (SADDLE) can be performed. The resulting structure can be used as a starting point to optimise the TS structure. In addition, the GRRM program has a function named IRC following (IRC) that can trace intrinsic reaction coordinates from the TS structure obtained by optimization. We used these tools to calculate the three autocatalytic reactions owing to the complexity of the TS structure. The reaction occurs via nucleophilic attack of the amine nitrogen on the terminal carbon of the epoxy functional group, followed by proton transfer, and Fig. 3 illustrates the general epoxy–amine reaction mechanism. The proton transfer is faster compared to the nucleophilic attack, and the nucleophilic attack occurs during the epoxy ring-opening step. Consequently, we identify the ring-opening reaction as the rate-determining step (r.d.s). In this reaction, a primary amine (PA) can react with two epoxy groups in two steps, as shown in Fig. 4 , which implies that the ratio of the base epoxy resin to the amine curing agent should be 2 to 1. The mechanism depicted in Fig. 3 represents a direct reaction pathway with no catalytic effect, involving only two molecules, regardless of the number of steps involved. Hence, this reaction is referred to as a two-body reaction. To investigate autocatalytic effects, we also explored three-body reactions in which the third body functions as a catalyst. Both reactants and products can act as third-body candidates. By considering autocatalysis, the E a and HOF can be obtained from GRRM, which is different from those of the two-body reaction. 2.2 Simulations of the crosslinking reactions In the MD simulation, the crosslinking model consists of two parts. The annealing part simulates the motion of the atoms in the system, while the reaction part determines whether the reaction occurs and produces new chemical bonds. Annealing. First, we obtained the initial model using Winmostar [23]. A total of 160 DGEBA and 80 2,2′-CH3-BP molecules were randomly placed into this system, and an initial density of 0.6 g/cm3 was chosen. An annealing operation by LAMMPS was then performed on the initial model as follows. To ensure full mixing, the system was first heated to 1000 K in an isochoric–isothermal (NVT) ensemble for 100 ps. The structure was then compressed to the appropriate density in an isothermal–isobaric (NPT) ensemble at 1000 K and 1 atm (101, 325 Pa) for 100 ps. Subsequently, it was cooled to 300 K at a cooling rate of 1012 K/s in the NVT ensemble for 700 ps and then maintained at 300 K and 1 atm in the NPT ensemble for 100 ps. Next, an annealing procedure was performed on the structure so as to properly relax the system. The annealing procedure was conducted by increasing the temperature from 300 K to 1000 K for 100 ps, cooling it to 300 K for 700 ps under the NVT ensemble, and then performing the NPT ensemble at 300 K and 1 atm for 100 ps. After nine cycles of annealing, the structure was fully relaxed under the NPT ensemble at 300 K and 1 atm for an additional 20 ns. The density changed from 0.6 g/cm3 to approximately 1.0 g/cm3 after the initial system was relaxed. At this higher density, active atomic sites can form bonds more easily and are closer to the natural state than at the initial density. In these procedures, the temperature was regulated using a Nosé–Hoover thermostat [24] in the NVT ensemble, whereas the temperature and pressure were controlled using the Martyna–Tobias–Klein-type (MTK-type) equations of motion [25] in the NPT ensemble. Periodic boundary conditions (PBCs) were implemented in all three directions, and a velocity–Verlet integrator [26] with a timestep of 1 fs was utilized throughout the whole simulation. Reaction part. We used LAMMPS and an in-house Python program to determine whether the reaction occurred. First, the relaxed uncrosslinked models were heated to 453 K (temperature used in the experiment) in an NVT ensemble for 50 ps. The structure was then compressed in an NPT ensemble (isotropic pressure coupling) at 453 K and 1 atm for 200 ps until the suitable density was obtained. We then considered the distance between the reactive parts to determine whether the reaction occurred. Fig. 5 shows the flow chart of our crosslinking simulation; the purple section is the unique section where the catalytic effect is considered. The distances between the carbon and nitrogen atoms (d C–N) were used to determine whether the epoxy–amine curing reaction occurred when d C–N was shorter than the cutoff distance (4.38 Å). The cutoff distance of 4.38 Å, used in previous studies [27], proved to be well-suited for our reaction. It represents the maximum distance between two atoms or molecules beyond which a chemical reaction cannot occur. The d C–N distances measured in the reactants along the GRRM-calculated reaction pathways when the reactions occurred, are listed in Table 1 . For both the direct and catalytic reactions, all the d C–N distances were smaller than the cutoff distance we set. In addition, the distance between the oxygen atom in the epoxide group and the hydrogen atom of the catalyst (d O–H) was used to judge whether there is catalyst participation. According to the d O–H in Table 1, we set the cutoff distance of d O–H as 2.2 Å, which means that when d O–H is less than 2.2 Å, the catalytic effect is taken into account. The reaction probability k was determined using the Arrhenius equation: (1) k = A exp ( − E a R T ) , where A is the acceleration constant bridging the time-scale gap between the experiment and MD simulations. It is set to 1015 to ensure that the reaction can be reproduced within a realistic computational time. E a represents the activation energy. When the d O–H of various catalytic molecules and epoxy groups is detected to be less than the cutoff distance 2.2 Å, the corresponding E a listed in Table 1 must be utilized. R is the gas constant, and T is the local temperature at the reaction site. The local temperature T can be calculated from the velocities of the surrounding atoms. (2) K E = d i m 2 N k B T where KE is the kinetic energy (∑1/2 mv2), dim is the simulation dimension (dim = 3 in this study), N is the number of atoms in the reaction site, and kB is the Boltzmann constant. Using the Monte Carlo method, a new bond is considered to be formed when k is larger than a generated uniform random number (P) between 0 and 1. Therefore, a new C–N bond was created. We updated the charges and velocities of the atoms and reassigned the force field. The HOF was then added to the reaction site as kinetic energy to change the velocity as follows: (3) ∑ 1 2 m v a f t e r 2 = H O F + ∑ 1 2 m v b e f o r e 2 where 1/2 mv 2 before and 1/2 mv 2 after denote the kinetic energies of the molecule before and after the reaction, respectively. The MD simulation and reaction calculation were repeated until the curing rate reached 80 %. The curing rate is a parameter to measure the curing reaction extent, as shown in the following equation: (4) a = N e p o x y r e a c t e d N e p o x y t o t a l × 100 ( % ) where Nepoxy total is the total number of epoxy groups before the reaction and Nepoxy reacted is the number of reacted epoxy groups in this model. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Calculations of the reaction routes Two-body systems. We calculated the energies of the first and second steps of the reaction in the direct reaction pathway (Fig. 6 ). There was little difference in the E a and HOF of the first and second steps, with the energy values of the first step being only slightly higher than those of the second. However, the E a of both steps was significantly higher than the E a obtained experimentally. The experimentally determined E a, provided by Professor Hajime Kishi of the Graduate School of Engineering at Hyogo University, Japan, falls within the range of 11–13 kcal/mol. These measurements were taken across temperatures ranging from 298.15 K to 573.15 K. The derivation of E a values was based on an analysis of the Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC) peaks, particularly noting variations when changing the heating rate. In this study, we compared our calculated E a values with the experimental data, rather than with the computed Gibbs free energy. This choice was grounded on the stability evaluation of structures throughout the reaction pathway. Reactants and products are relatively stable, leading to consistent energy estimations, even at elevated temperatures. However, TS structures, due to their inherent instability, may provide less reliable energy estimations at elevated temperatures. We conducted free energy calculations at 453 K and observed a difference of approximately 5 kcal/mol compared to the E a at 0 K. At this temperature, the deviation is manageable. However, as temperatures increase, especially considering the local temperature T at the reactive site as detailed in Eq. (1), which can occasionally approach 1000 K, the energy predictions for TS structures become less reliable. Considering these variables, we opted for the use of E a over free energy in our calculations. The difference between our calculations and experimental data might be attributed to overlooking factors like autocatalysis and water catalysis. While this study integrated the autocatalysis reaction, the effects of water catalysis will be a focal point of our future research. Three-body systems. Fig. 7 shows a schematic illustration of the three different body complexes used in the TSs. Hydrogen-donating groups such as R–NH2, R–NH, and R–OH can combine with epoxy groups via intermolecular hydrogen bonds to form three-body complexes, where they act as catalysts. The catalysts participate in curing reactions either by using their basicity as the hydrogen-bonding pathway or their nucleophilicity as the ring-opening pathway, where the key catalytic effect is to facilitate epoxy ring opening prior to curing by an acid [28]. Here, in addition, the amino group of 2,2′-CH3-BP formed a hydrogen bond with the oxygen atom of DGEBA in a six-membered ring structure, which also reduced the E a. Three reaction pathways for the three-body reaction with R–NH2, R–NH, and R–OH, respectively, as the catalyst are shown in Fig. 8 . All three reaction pathways had two TS structures and an intermediate structure; the energy of the first TS structure was the largest. Similar to the two-body reaction, the first TS structure in the three-body reaction pathway also had the ring-opening step as the rate-determining step. Table 1 shows the E a and reaction atom distances of the two-body and three-body models required for the MD simulations. When the catalytic effect was added, the E a of the first step (E a-1st) decreased by 20–30 kcal/mol. However, in the second step, the molecule was relatively large, resulting in steric crowding. Moreover, the autocatalyzed six-membered ring structure was not conducive to reducing the E a, as the cyclic arrangement forced an unfavourable nucleophilic syn-attack [10]. Thus, in the cross-linking simulations, only the direct reaction was considered for the second-step reaction. The results also indicate that the reaction catalysed by an alcohol group (R–OH) has the lowest E a for the first-step reaction. 3.2 Simulations of the cross-link reaction In this section, we introduce two models constructed using the DREIDING force field in LAMMPS, supplemented by an in-house Python program. System 1 focuses on direct reactions, while System 2 incorporates both direct and autocatalytic reactions, as depicted in Fig. 5. After attaining a target curing rate of 80 % with these models, their thermomechanical properties were evaluated at 300 K, a temperature corresponding with typical experimental conditions. Following these, we simulated density, volume shrinkage, glass transition temperature, and Young's modulus. Note that the initial model, relaxation, and mechanical property calculations for both systems were performed using a consistent method. The only difference between System 1 and System 2 is the type of reaction part, as described in Section 2.2: System 1 considers only direct reactions to calculate the reaction probability k, while System 2 considers three autocatalytic reactions and calculates k using the corresponding E a. To verify the MD simulation, which typically requires multiple polymer samples to be tested due to the dependence of the initial polymer structure on the mechanical properties, we created five completely independent samples for each system and performed calculations to evaluate the impact of autocatalytic effects on the resin performance. Validation of structure crosslinking. As the curing rate increased, the size of the largest molecules gradually increased. When the curing rate of the model reached 80 %, the weight percentage of the largest molecule was more than 90 %, as shown in Fig. 9 . These results indicate that the monomers successfully underwent crosslinking, regardless of whether the reaction was direct or autocatalytic. Gelation. The gel point was determined by monitoring the molecular weights of the largest and second-largest molecules. As the gel point was approached, the molecular weight of the largest molecule increased significantly, while the molecular weight of the second largest molecule decreased accordingly. As shown in Fig. 9, the gel point occurred at approximately 60 % conversion for both the systems and the results were in good agreement with the theoretical predictions [29,30]. Density increases and volume shrinkage. Due to crosslinking, polymer structures undergo compaction upon curing. We therefore compared the densities and volume shrinkage of the two systems at an 80 % curing rate. The density and volume shrinkage were calculated based on the average of five samples. The densities of both systems at 300 K were highly similar at approximately 1.03 g/cm3 (the error was very low at ∼0.1 % and was thus ignored); they were slightly smaller than the experimental result of 1.1 g/cm3 (provided by Professor Hajime Kishi), which was attributed to the DREIDING force field [1,8,31]. There was a larger difference in the volume shrinkage of System 1 and System 2, with values of 1.73 ± 0.22% and 2.13 ± 0.34 %, respectively; the volume shrinkage of System 2 was closer to previously reported experimental measurements of crosslinking-induced volume shrinkage (2.0–5.3 %) [32]. Young’s Modulus. Young’s modulus quantifies the relationship between tensile stress and strain. To evaluate the Young's modulus, we conducted uniaxial tensile MD simulations at 300 K [29]. In these simulations, the system was elongated up to a strain of 20 % at a constant strain rate of 107 s−1. Fig. 10 illustrates the uniaxial stress-strain curve, where stress is denoted as σ and strain as ε. We conducted separate simulations along the x, y, and z directions and determined the final Young's modulus by averaging the values obtained from each axis. For each axis, we derived a linear fit of the stress-strain curve within the strain range of 1 % to 4 %, as highlighted by the red straight line in Fig. 10. The slope of this fit denotes the Young's modulus for the corresponding axis. The Young's modulus of systems 1 and 2 were 3.02 ± 0.11 GPa and 3.12 ± 0.08 GPa, respectively, based on the average of results from five samples. The experimental Young's modulus was found to be 3.32 GPa (provided by Professor Hajime Kishi), which was closer to the Young's modulus of System 2 than that of System 1. Glass transition temperature. Glass transition temperature (T g) refers to the temperature at which the polymer transitions from a glass state to a rubbery state and can be determined from the relationship between temperature and density or volume. In this study, we determined the T g by first relaxing the crosslinked model at 200 K under NPT conditions, followed by heating the cell from 200 to 700 K at a rate of 2.5 × 1010 K/s. Our previous study [13] explains the rationale behind selecting this temperature range and rate. The change in the slope of the density–temperature curve indicates T g. However, as the MD simulation model used in this study is relatively small, the T g data exhibited large fluctuations. Therefore, to better visualise the relationship between temperature and density, we performed linear fitting on the data to obtain a curve, as shown by the solid red line in Fig. 11 . The average block volume was calculated at temperature increments of 0.1 K, and the resulting curve was fitted with straight lines on the left and right sides, as depicted in Fig. 11. More precisely, on the left side, we defined the data range as 200 K to T, where T represents every 0.1 K increment from 230 K to 700 K; the range of 200–230 K was eliminated as it was deemed unnecessary. We then calculated the root-mean-square error (RMSE) divided by N d , where Nd represents the number of data points, to account for the reliability of the linear fitting. This method is the same as that introduced in a previous study [13]. For both Systems 1 and 2, we chose the ‘left minimum’ temperature as the best fitting when RMSE/ N d was used to establish the minimum temperature, and then linearised the density–temperature curve from 200 K to the ‘left minimum’ using the least-squares method for five data points. Similarly, on the right side, we defined the data range as T to 700 K (T is every 0.1 K increment from 200 to 700 K), calculated RMSE/ N d chose the ‘right minimum’ temperature, and linearised the density–temperature curve from the ‘right minimum’ to 700 K using the least-squares method. The junction point was established by fitting the density profile with two straight lines for the two regions: one from 200 K to the left minimum and the other from the right minimum to 700 K. Based on the average of the results from the five samples, the T g values for Systems 1 and 2 were predicted to be 450.68 ± 17.16 K and 471.03 ± 26.87 K, respectively, while the experimentally measured T g was 468.15 K (provided by Professor Hajime Kishi). Both the Young's modulus and T g of the two systems differed, and the values for System 2 were closer to the experimental values. However, there was not much difference between the densities of the two systems. To investigate this phenomenon, we determined the types and corresponding quantities of crosslinks. Crosslinking. Crosslinking is the formation of a bond between two polymer chains. Fig. 12 shows six different types of crosslinks—(a) Type 1: forms when the curing agent 2,2′-CH3-BP does not react; (b) Type 2: forms when the first-step reaction occurs between the terminal amine group of 2,2′-CH3-BP and the terminal epoxy group of DGEBA (the primary amine is converted to a secondary amine, which is identical to the structure generated in the first-step reaction shown in Fig. 4); (c) Type 3: forms when both ends of 2,2′-CH3-BP undergo the first-step reaction; (d) Type 4: forms when the first- and second-step reactions occur at the same end of 2,2′-CH3-BP (the secondary amine is converted to a tertiary amine); (e) Type 5: forms when the first-step reaction occurs at one end of 2,2′-CH3-BP, and both the first- and second-step reactions occur at the other end, resulting in a total of three reactions; and (f) Type 6: forms when both ends of 2,2′-CH3-BP undergo the two-step reaction, resulting in a total of four reactions. Table 2 presents the proportion of crosslinks of each type in the systems. We then calculated the monomeric degree index (MDI), which is the average number of monomeric units covalently bonded to a given monomeric unit; the values were obtained from the average of the calculations for five samples and are presented in Table 2. The MDI has been proven to be useful in comparing the effects of different curing mechanisms on the thermo-mechanical properties of polymers, and monomer functionality has a significant influence on the Young's modulus. An MDI value of approximately 3 is in good agreement with the values of previous studies [33]. In our study, we calculated not only the basic MDI for the six types of crosslinks but also the MDI for the crosslink types that predominantly contributed to the crosslinking network, hereinafter referred to as MDI-C. Crosslink types 1, 2, and 4 were excluded from the calculation of MDI-C, as they did not contribute to the skeleton. Due to catalysis, the E a of the first-step reaction significantly reduced, resulting in System 2 having more type-3 and -5 crosslinks than System 1. Furthermore, System 2 had a higher MDI-C than System 1. This may provide an explanation for the Young's modulus of System 2 being higher than that of System 1. As indicated in Table 2, type-6 crosslinks were of the highest proportion in System 1, while type-5 crosslinks were the most common in System 2. Type-3 crosslinks were also greater in number in System 2 than in System 1. The polarity of R–NH in type-5 crosslinks is greater than that of R–N in type-6 crosslinks, thus increasing the intermolecular force. For example, the R–NH in type-3 and type-5 crosslinks can form hydrogen bonds, demonstrating the influence of polarity on molecular interactions. This can be evidenced by the partial radial distribution functions, often denoted as gαβ (r) [8]. This specific type of radial distribution function can describe how density varies as a function of distance from a reference particle within a system. The "partial" means that it only considers a pair of specific types of particles, denoted by α and β. Fig. 13 presents gαβ (r) for the H–H, C–H, C–C, O–H, C–O, N–H, C–N, O–O, O–N, and N–N pairs in the systems. The increased polarity in System 2 is reflected in the gαβ (r) of the O–N atomic pair, which exhibits a more pronounced peak around 3 Å range relative to System 1. This distinct peak indicates a tendency for oxygen and nitrogen atoms in System 2 to congregate at this particular interval. This observation is probably attributable to the formation of hydrogen bonds, a specific type of non-covalent interaction that occurs when a hydrogen atom, covalently bonded to a donor atom, is donated to an electronegative acceptor atom. The mean donor-acceptor distances in secondary structure elements are approximately 3.0 Å [34], which is consistent with our observed peak for the O–N pair at around 3 Å. This suggests that the increased atomic interactions at this distance could be due to the formation of electrostatic hydrogen bonds. Hydrogen bonding is one of the main factors that stabilizes the structure of epoxy-based composites and improves their mechanical properties. Oya et al. showed a base resin with four epoxy groups creates a superior cross-linked network resulting in stronger mechanical properties than a base resin with two functional groups by both covalent bonding and hydrogen bonding [35]. Furthermore, previous studies have shown that strong intermolecular interactions play an important role in increasing the T g value [36], explaining the higher T g of System 2 compared to that of System 1. From the foregoing analysis, it becomes apparent that the incorporation of catalysis in the crosslinking process significantly impacts the physical properties of the simulated model. This is because, when catalysis is accounted for, the reaction E a in the initial step is reduced, resulting in a different proportion of each crosslink type. 4 Conclusion We investigated the reaction pathway and mechanism of epoxy curing using the GRRM program and found that autocatalysis reduced the E a of the first step of the reaction (primary to secondary amine conversion) by approximately 30 kcal/mol. The cross-linking model was then developed using the energy values obtained from the GRRM and MD simulations with a reaction model involving catalysis. Here, we performed cross-linking simulations for two systems: one with only a direct reaction, and one that also considered an autocatalytic reaction. The resulting physical properties of the two systems were compared. The Young's modulus and Tg were closer to the experimental data when considering the autocatalytic effect. We then accounted for the different Young's modulus and T g of the two systems by calculating the crosslinking types and MDIs. We found that considering autocatalysis resulted in a lower E a, which had a great influence on the type of crosslinking reaction, which in turn affected the physical properties. The cat-GRRM/MC/MD method therefore successfully reduced the deviation between the simulation and experimental results of the curing reaction of epoxy resin. Indeed, these findings, regarding the role of molecular catalysts in influencing the proportion of crosslink types and subsequently the physical properties, provide valuable insights into polymerization processes. This could pave the way for more efficient design and optimization strategies in the production of advanced materials, demonstrating both theoretical and practical implications for material science and industry. coredata.dc:description: Epoxy resins, which are common matrices in carbon fibre-reinforced plastics, are derived from the curing of epoxy amines. Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations are commonly used to model the physical properties of such network polymers, but they do not account for chemical reactions. Quantum chemical (QC) calculations can elucidate reaction mechanisms and energies but are not suitable for models with thousands of atoms. To address these limitations, in this study, we developed a new method, cat-GRRM/MC/MD, that combines QC calculations in the Global Reaction Route Mapping (GRRM) program with reaction simulations involved in MD simulation methods. This approach allows the simulation of reaction pathways in which proton donor molecules such as alcohols and amines act as molecular catalysts (autocatalysis), and the reaction kinetics are realised in a Monte Carlo (MC) manner. Our results show that autocatalysis significantly reduces the activation energy of the epoxy resin reaction, bringing the calculated data closer to the experimental results. When these quantum chemical calculations were incorporated into MD simulations, it was found that the activation energy influenced the crosslinking results. Models including catalysis led to network polymers with larger carbon skeletons, and physical properties such as the Young's modulus and glass transition temperature become closer to experimental results. This study not only deepens our understanding of the mechanism of the self-catalytic reaction of epoxy resins but also provides a new tool for accurately simulating the performance of epoxy resins, thus enabling more precise control of their properties.
coredata.dc:title: Development of cat-GRRM/MC/MD method for the simulation of cross-linked network structure formation with molecular autocatalysis
